title: Natural and Alternative Treatments for Lung Cancer
author: Alyson Powell Key
description: While they're not a cure, natural therapies can help to ease side effects and symptoms of lung cancer. What's the difference between complementary and alternative medicine, and what should you look out for before trying this type of therapy?
cleaned_text: When you have [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/default.htm), you'll want to do everything you can to get well and feel better during treatment. [Chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/chemotherapy-what-to-expect), surgery, and [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) are the usual treatments. But many people with cancer also explore other therapies, like [yoga](https://www.webmd.com/balance/the-health-benefits-of-yoga) and [acupuncture](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/consider-acupuncture). Many major hospitals even offer some of these therapies together with mainstream medicine. Complementary medicine isn't a [lung cancer](https://www.webmd.com/lung-cancer/understanding-lung-cancer-symptoms) cure, but it can ease your symptoms and the side effects of traditional treatments. Complementary and Alternative Medicine (CAM) Even though they might seem similar, "complementary" and "alternative" mean different things when it comes to [lung cancer treatments](https://www.webmd.com/lung-cancer/guide/consumer-guide-chapter-outline): - Complementary or [integrative medicine](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/alternative-medicine-integrative-medicine). Doctors pair this with standard treatments like chemotherapy, surgery, and radiation. Most of the time, the goal is to manage symptoms and side effects like pain, an [upset stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), and [sleep](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/default.htm)problems. [Alternative medicine](https://www.webmd.com/balance/what-is-alternative-medicine). People with [lung cancer](https://www.webmd.com/lung-cancer/understanding-lung-cancer-prevention)usually choose these treatments instead of the usual ones, or when traditional therapies don't work. CAM Categories and Treatments Complementary and alternative medicine breaks down into five main categories: - Alternative medical systems are whole systems of therapy and practice, like homeopathic or naturopathic medicine. - Mind-body interventions are techniques to enhance your mind's effect on your body. - Herbalism uses plants as a treatment. - Manipulative and body-based methods involve moving or touching different parts of the body; for example, [chiropractic](https://www.webmd.com/back-pain/chiropractic-pain-relief)and [massage therapy](https://www.webmd.com/balance/massage-therapy-styles-and-health-benefits). - Energy therapies seek to bring outside energy to you or to balance the energy inside you. Some types use sound, light, and magnets, and others use touch or movement. Under this umbrella of categories, you'll find more than 100 individual CAM treatments. Some of them can ease [cancer symptoms](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/understanding-cancer-symptoms): [Yoga](https://www.webmd.com/fitness-exercise/ss/slideshow-yoga-pose-basics)is a low-impact series of poses that emphasizes [breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/how-we-breathe). Studies have shown that it can have benefits for strength, energy, and [mental health](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/default.htm)for people who have even advanced [lung cancer](https://www.webmd.com/lung-cancer/what-is-lung-cancer). - Massage puts pressure on your [skin](https://www.webmd.com/beauty/cosmetic-procedures-overview-skin)and muscles. It can help to ease [pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/default.htm)and [anxiety](https://www.webmd.com/anxiety-panic/default.htm). [Reiki](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/reiki-overview)is a Japanese technique that uses touch to lower [stress](https://www.webmd.com/balance/stress-management/default.htm)and help with relaxation and healing. [Acupuncture](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/ss/slideshow-acupuncture-overview)inserts thin needles into your skin. Research shows that it can ease nausea in people who have cancer. - Guided imagery or visualization is when you think of sights, sounds, and scents connected to reaching a goal or state of mind. Studies have shown that it can ease [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/default.htm), raise feelings of well-being, and temporarily boost the number of your immune cells. [Dietary supplements](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/supplement-faq)are [vitamins](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/lifestyle-guide-11/default.htm), [minerals](https://www.webmd.com/food-recipes/vitamin-mineral-sources), of [brain training](https://www.webmd.com/brain/video/brain-training)that could lessen pain and [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/understanding-depression-basics)and improve energy and [sleep](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-disorders-faq). Some say that "natural" therapies like herbal medicine, [cannabis](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/marijuana-use-and-its-effects#1) oil, laetrile (a purified form of a compound found in fruit pits or seeds), or other plant-based foods can kill cancer cells. There's little or no scientific evidence to support these claims. Putting Standard and CAM Treatments Together If you're thinking about trying complementary treatment, you'll want to make sure that it doesn't get in the way of your standard [lung cancer treatments](https://www.webmd.com/lung-cancer/guide/lung-cancer-treatment) or cause side effects. Ask yourself and your doctor these questions: - Will it affect any current cancer treatments? - Does research show whether it's effective? - Are there any side effects? - Will your cancer care and CAM teams work together? - If you have [insurance](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/default.htm), will it cover treatment costs, or will you need to pay [out of pocket](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/default.htm)? Research shows that people with cancer who combine complementary and standard therapies will often turn down further traditional treatments. This can lead to a lower 5-year survival rate and a higher chance of death. Before you start or stop any new or current therapy, talk to your doctor. Things to Look Out For Natural and alternative treatments can make you feel better. But some are harmful, and sometimes there's no science to prove they're safe or effective. Plus, the people who promote them as a cure may not have a background in medicine. Steer clear of treatments or providers that: - Claim to cure cancer - Tell you to stop your regular treatment - Are a "secret" - Require you to go to another country to get - Refuse to work with your doctor or [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca)provider You can also check with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) for more information about [cancer treatment](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/understanding-cancer-treatment) frauds.
